captions.text: Are you laughing at me?

No.
Are you rejecting me?

l'm sure
that the feelings which,
as you've told me...

have hindered your regard
will help you
in overcoming it.
Might l ask why...

with so little endeavor
at civility,
l am thus repulsed?

And l might as well
enquire why...

with so evident a design
of insulting me...

you chose to tell me
that you liked me...

against
your better judgment!
No, believe me--

lf l was uncivil,
then that is some excuse!

But l have other reasons.
You know l have.
What reasons?

Do you think that
anything might tempt me
to accept the man...

who has ruined,
perhaps forever...

the happiness
of a most beloved sister?
Do you deny it, Mr. Darcy?

That you separated
a young couple
who loved each other...

exposing your friend
to the center
of the world for caprice...

and my sister to its derision
for disappointed hopes.

And involving them both
in misery
of the acutest kind?
l do not deny it.
How could you do it?

Because l believed your sister
indifferent to him.
lndifferent?

l watched them
most carefully...

and realized his attachment
was deeper than hers.

That's because
she's shy.
Bingley, too, is modest...

and was persuaded
she didn't feel
strongly for him.

Because you suggested it.
l did it for his own good.

My sister hardly shows
her true feelings to me!

l suppose you suspect
that his fortune
had some bearing--

No! l wouldn't do your sister
the dishonor!

Though it was suggested--
What was?

lt was made
perfectly clear that
an advantageous marriage--

Did my sister
give that impression?
No! No!

No. There was, however,
l have to admit,
the matter of your family.
Our want of connection?

Mr. Bingley didn't seem to vex
himself about that.

No, it was more than that.
How, sir?

lt was
the lack of propriety...

shown by your mother,
your three younger sisters...

even, on occasion,
your father.
[thunder rumbling]
Forgive me.

You and your sister
l must exclude from this.
And what about Mr. Wickham?
Mr. Wickham?

What excuse can you give
for your behavior towards him?

You take an eager interest
in that gentleman's concerns.

He told me
of his misfortunes.

Oh, yes, his misfortunes
have been very great indeed.

You ruin his chances,
and yet you treat him
with sarcasm?
So this is your opinion of me.

Thank you
for explaining so fully.

Perhaps these offenses
might have been overlooked
had not your...

pride been hurt
by my honesty...
My pride?

...in admitting scruples
about our relationship.

Could you expect me
to rejoice...

in the inferiority
of your circumstances?

And those are the words
of a gentleman.

From the first moment
l met you...

your arrogance and conceit,
your selfish disdain...
for the feelings of others...

made me realize that you were
the last man in the world...

l could ever be prevailed upon
to marry.

Forgive me, madam,
for taking up
so much of your time.
[sighs]

title: Pride & Prejudice (6/10) Movie CLIP - Elizabeth's Pride (2005) HD

Ahhhhh, the 'car crash scene'. Love it!!! One of the best confrontation

comments.author: Venusbabe66

comments.text:
A very meaningful movie, although it could´ve been a bit longer to show 
more of the society back then. Also some implied scenes, which refer to the 
book got lost in the film, also because of the language. But nevertheless 
it´s interesting to see what they´ve made out of the book and how funny 
scenes were put in.
This scene especially reminds me of the book (like Darcy´s nervous and both 
serious attitude) and amazes me again how little facial expressions can say 
so much. Best film version, I think ! And the romantic feelings are shown 
so passionately although they do not kiss at all. Because this is what 
transports the feelings the best !﻿

comments.author: Nikia Delaney

comments.text:
+Gerard Jagroo That's just the thing. If all the things that happened, 
hadn't, Elizabeth probably would have liked Darcy a lot sooner, rather than 
just being attracted to him, and trying to avoid him.
 I think, without realizing it, she felt attracted to him, that is why she 
was so hostile in her words towards him, because she wished that the man 
she felt a connection to wouldn't hurt the people she cares about, and ends 
up hating herself for her feelings towards him. She didn't act on her 
attraction. And just because you think someone's attractive, doesn't mean 
you like who they seem to be. So when a girl says "You're so sweet." at 
least she sees his character right away, (and when some girls say that, 
they are waiting for you to take action.) unlike someone who, lets say is 
like Wickham, and you are attracted, to him because he seems "Sweet and 
Mysterious.", and you get slapped in the face by a bucket of cold, harsh, 
reality and realize he's a jerk who messed with your emotions.
Elizabeth had been attracted to Darcy the minute she saw him, you can't 
help who you get attracted too, it's just a small, sometimes torturing, 
part of life. Some people are ashamed of being attracted to the wrong 
people, so don't just think all woman want to throw themselves to a guy 
they like. Also, if at the end of the day a guy is complaining about a girl 
not having feelings back for him, and how she's an idiot for not choosing 
him, since he is supposedly the "Nice guy", than I would rather disagree 
and say he is the one who does not deserve her. Because even "nice guys" 
have been liked by the "nice girl", and that "nice girl" had her heart 
broken too. It's just life. You don't get to force someone to make what you 
think is the right decision. Or at the end of the day, you are the wrong 
guy.    And I know it's hard to believe, but you cannot fit all woman into 
one tiny box, we could do the same, and I believe we probably already do. 
Either way it's not right on either sides.
comments.author: WonderStruck57

comments.text:
How pedestrian a comment....given that as usual....you are contrasting 300 
pages of text against a 2 hour movie.....and yet the absolutely typical 
expectation is that every nuanced expression in a written work are going to 
be faithfully reproduced in a work as compressed as a visually centric work 
such as a movie....the epic fail ...I. Am afraid is your rather immature 
expectation of perfect reflection of a work as you recall it...yet somehow 
in a different medium...
comments.author: zeroceiling

comments.text:
The film fails miserably in expressing Elizabeth's thoughts and feelings 
that were expressed in the book. Epic fail here read the novel and you 
shall see.
comments.author: rich paris

comments.text:
Good movie but they failed to portray the original language from the novel. 
I am quite sure they did it on purpose to make it easier to understand but 
it took something away from the film for me. Especially in this particular 
scene when Elizabeth says "you liked me against your better judgement." 
That takes away one of the best quotes of the entire novel. "why with so 
evident a desire of offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that 
you liked me against your will, against your reason, and even against your 
character?"﻿
